title: 104_hr3943
content: The Earned Income Credit for individuals with children is determined without regard to the number of children, with specific percentages for the credit and phaseout. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage for individuals not filing a joint return are 15% and 11% respectively, while for married individuals filing jointly, the percentages are 18.5% and 10% respectively. The earned income amount for individuals not filing a joint return is $11,000 with a phaseout amount of $11,600. For married individuals filing jointly, the earned income amount is $9,000 with a phaseout amount of $12,000. The definition of an eligible individual under section 32 of the Code is amended to include those with a qualifying child. The term "adjusted gross income" is replaced with "modified adjusted gross income" in various subsections of the Code. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is defined as adjusted gross income increased by certain amounts and excluding specific deductions, such as Social Security benefits not included in gross income. Amounts received by a spouse under a divorce or separation instrument for child support exceeding $6,000, and tax-exempt interest received or accrued during the taxable year are included in the taxable income. The taxable income includes amounts received as a pension, annuity, or from an individual retirement plan, excluding certain amounts not included in gross income. Losses from sales or exchanges of capital assets exceeding gains are also disregarded. The curr_chunk discusses the net loss from trades or businesses, estates and trusts, and excess amounts from sales or exchanges. The curr_chunk discusses inflation adjustments for phaseout amounts in the tax code. The curr_chunk explains how dollar amounts in the tax code related to phaseout amounts are adjusted for inflation starting in 1997. The tax code provisions for married individuals filing joint returns are adjusted for inflation starting in 1997. The credit percentage for individuals not filing joint returns is increased by the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. Married individuals filing joint returns also have their credit percentage increased accordingly. The credit percentage for individuals not filing joint returns is increased by the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, rounded to the nearest 1/100th of 1 percent. Elimination of personal exemption for dependents under 18. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code eliminates the personal exemption for dependents under 18 years old. Dependent must be 18 years old by the end of the calendar year for the taxpayer to claim an exemption. Coordination with other provisions is required for deductions related to dependents. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code removes personal exemption for dependents under 18. Dependent must be 18 by year-end for taxpayer to claim exemption. Amendment adjusts age requirement in tax code. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code removes personal exemption for dependents under 18. New section 35A allows credit for children under 18. The new section allows a taxpayer to claim a child credit amount for each qualifying child based on earned income. The credit amount is limited by the earned income amount and initial phasedown amount. The credit percentage and earned income amount are determined by the sum of the initial phasedown amount and the final phasedown amount. The credit percentage and earned income amount for qualifying children are as follows: 1st and 2nd child - 12.5% and $8,000, 3rd child - 4% and $25,000, 4th child and beyond - 3.33% and $30,000. The initial phasedown amount is determined based on the taxpayer's income exceeding $75,000 for individuals ($110,000 for joint filers) or $210, whichever is lower. The final phasedown amount is calculated as 2 percentage points for each $2,500 by which the taxpayer's income exceeds the threshold amount for the year. The section defines terms like earned income and qualifying child for tax purposes, with specific thresholds and percentages applied. The table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new item after section 35. Section 35A allows for a credit for dependents under 18 years of age. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1996.
